channel.title: SHELL Scripts
channel.description:
After using windows for a long time I have finally had enough and converted to a unix based operating system. I had gotten used to how windows worked with the command prompt and batch files.
Now I get to use shell scripts instead of batch. When I try using shell scripts I have made it alerts me that I don't have the privileges and I was wondering how you chmod the script so it is executable.
Because the JDK is built into this operating system and the paths are already set is this how I would go about running a java class:
[code]#! /bin/sh java ./MainClass.class[/code]

item.title: SHELL Scripts
item.dc:creator: @linkmaster03 linkmaster03
item.description:
@linkmaster03 wrote:

T4_:

Wrong, you never should use sudo su, it’s sudo OR su.

“sudo su” is a workaround that Ubuntu users use because Canonical disabled the root account by default rofl. “sudo -i” is the preferred solution to switch to a root shell.

Read full topic

item.title: SHELL Scripts
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

nano script

#!/bin/sh
java MainClass.class

sh script

You’re done.

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:267220”]sudo su

Type that in terminal and then your root password to gain root access[/quote]
Wrong, you never should use sudo su, it’s sudo OR su.

Read full topic

item.title: SHELL Scripts
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:267220”]sudo su

Type that in terminal and then your root password to gain root access[/quote]

Wrong

Ollie:

sudo chmod 755 script.sh

Correct (somewhat, you don’t need root to change privileges on a file you own)

chmod +x script.sh

is somewhat equivalent to ollie’s.

also, you script is wrong.

should be

#!/bin/sh

without a space.

Read full topic

item.title: SHELL Scripts
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

sudo su

Type that in terminal and then your root password to gain root access

Read full topic
